all_paragraphs: This article provides detailed implementation of dimensionality reduction technique for Hyperspectral Images(HSI).

Hyperspectral Image(HSI) provides a wide range of spectral information that can be used to address a variety of problems like crop analysis, geological mapping, mineral exploration, etc. Due to the presence of a large number of bands in the data, Dimensionality reduction has become an important aspect of machine learning. It is often considered as a preprocessing step to solve machine learning problems such as classification and clustering. In general, the accuracy of any classification and clustering algorithm will be influenced by the number of dimensions or features.

The dimensionality reduction techniques are used to reduce the number of dimensions of the dataset, thereby paving the way for the classifiers to generate comprehensive models at a low computational cost. Hence, Dimensionality Reduction (DR) has become more prominent to improve the accuracy of pixel classification in Hyperspectral Images(HSI).
To get a better understanding on HSI, use below article entitled “Hyperspectral Image Analysis — Getting Started”.
Dimensionality Reduction is a process of reducing dimensions or features of the dataset. The dimensions of the dataset can be reduced by using two ways. They are:

Feature Selection is the process of selecting dimensions of features of the dataset which contributes mode to the machine learning tasks such as classification, clustering, e.t.c. This can be achieved by using different methods such as correlation analysis, univariate analysis, e.t.c.

Feature Extraction Feature Extraction is a process of finding new features by selecting and/or combining existing features to create reduced feature space, while still accurately and completely describing the data set without loss of information.

Based on the criterion function and process of convergence, dimensionality reduction techniques are also classified as Convex and Non-Convex. Some popular dimensionality reduction techniques include PCA, ICA, LDA, GDA, Kernel PCA, Isomap, Local linear embedding(LLE), Hessian LLE, etc.
We are going to use Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to reduce the dimensions of the HSI.

PCA is a linear unsupervised dimensionality reduction technique that can be described as an eigen decomposition of the covariance matrix of the data. It increases the interpretability by reducing the information loss by creating uncorrelated features with maximized variance.

The curse of dimensionality refers to the phenomenon that arises when classifying, analyzing data in high dimensional space that do not occur in low dimensional space. As the dimensions or features increase after an optimal point the classification performance gradually decreases.

The Pavia University Dataset is utilized for illustration purposes. The HSI scene acquired by the ROSIS sensor during a flight campaign over Pavia, northern Italy. The number of spectral bands is 103, the size of HSI is 610*340 pixels, the ground truth contains 9 classes. Some of the pixels in images contain no information and have to be discarded before the analysis.

Let’s reduce the dimensions of Pavia University HSI. First of all, How many dimensions should we reduce?.

Using the Explained Variance Ratio Graph we can select the optimal number of dimensions to be reduced. The x-axis of graphs represents the number of principal components and the y-axis represents the cumulative explained variance. We can select the number of components which have >95% cumulative explained variance. In this case, we selected 8 number of principal components i.e., we are reducing the dimensions of the Pavia University data to 8 dimensions.
